awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Analysis and Geometry of Measures
awd_abstract_narration:
Geometric measure theory is a field of mathematics that evolved from investigations in the 1920s and 1930s into the structure of sets in the plane with finite length. The term "measure" refers to an abstract generalization of length, area, or volume, which assigns a size value to every mathematical set. Traditional outlets for geometric measure theory have expanded in recent decades. The widespread utility and current use of geometric measure theory in different areas of analysis justifies its continued development. The research component of this project seeks to advance our understanding about underlying structures of general measures and to develop new techniques that will expand the toolbox that geometric measure theory provides for researchers in adjacent areas of analysis and geometry. On the educational front, this project will support a network of early career researchers whose research involves nonsmooth analysis, including graduate students and postdoctoral researchers who work in a number areas.  Principal activities by the PI include organizing a Workshop for Postdocs in Fall 2017 and a Conference for Graduate Students with Mini-Courses in Spring 2019. The two conferences will be linked: postdoctoral participants from the workshop will be invited to give mini-courses for graduate students in the follow-up conference. The PI will further integrate research and education by organizing an analysis learning seminar and mentoring two postdoctoral researchers at the PI's home institution.

This project focuses on a constellation of questions about the structure of Radon measures in Euclidean space. The underlying theme is that general measures may be understood in terms of their behavior with respect to lower dimensional sets such as finite length curves in the plane and finite area surfaces in space. This point-of-view originated in the 1920s and 1930s through investigations by A.S. Besicovitch, which compared and contrasted properties of finite length sets with properties of rectifiable curves.  Later contributions by A.P. Morse and J.F. Randolph, H. Federer, P. Mattila, and D. Preiss from the 1940s through the 1980s produced a rich theory of qualitative rectifiability of measures in Euclidean space that are absolutely continuous with respect to Hausdorff measures; a quantitative theory of rectifiability for Ahlfors regular measures emerged in the 1990s through the work of G. David and S. Semmes. The proposed research seeks to broaden our understanding of different notions of rectifiability of measures in the absence of background regularity hypotheses from past investigations. Specifically, the PI will look for characterizations of Radon measures which are carried by countable families of Hölder continuous curves, Lipschitz graphs, or Lipschitz continuous images of linear subspaces. This goal requires integration of techniques from modern harmonic analysis and quantitative geometric measure theory. The PI will explore approaches based on the PI's work with R. Schul, which characterized Radon measures that are carried by countable families of rectifiable curves, as well as approaches based on G. David and T. Toro's extension of the Reifenberg algorithm and approaches based on K. Rajala's quasiconformal uniformization theorem.

por.por_cntn:
Educational activities of the award centered around a pair of linked conferences for early career mathematicians: a fall 2017 workshop for postdoctoral researchers in nonsmooth analysis, with an emphasis on professional development, and a spring 2019 conference for graduate students in geometric and harmonic analysis, with mini-courses by some of the workshop participants. The conference attracted around 70 participants and had 43 contributed short talks by graduate students from across the United States. The mini-courses were

  • "Compactness Methods and Blow-ups in Harmonic Analysis and Geometric Measure Theory" by Max Engelstein (MIT)
  • "Bellman Functions: Probability Methods in Harmonic Analysis" by Irina Holmes (Michigan State University / Texas A&M)
  • "Hausdorff Dimension" by Bobby Wilson (University of Washington)

At the end of this award, 11 of the 13 postdoc participants (including 3 female mathematicians and 1 African-American mathematician) secured tenure-line positions in the United States, including positions at Lousiana State University, Texas A&M University, The Ohio State University Marion, University of Alabama, University of Houston Clear Lake, University of Minnesota, University of Tennessee, and University of Washington, and in Europe (United Kingdom, Spain). This confirmed the thesis that peer mentorship is a superior mode of training for early career scientists.

The award also provided research assistantships for 3 graduate students at UConn over the 5-year period: Lisa Naples (3 semesters), Christopher Hayes (1 semester), and Erik Wendt (1 semester). Naples completed her thesis in geometric measure theory under the direction of the PI and secured a postdoctoral position at Macalester College.

Research conducted under this award resulted in 6 published articles, 4 additional preprints submitted for publication, and 4 additional manuscripts in preparation. Publications appeared in high quality mathematical journals, including Advances in Mathematics, Bulletin of the London Mathematical Society, and Revista Matematica Iberoamericana.

Research findings were disseminated by the PI in an invited Plenary Talk at the 8th Ohio River Analysis Meeting in March 2018, and at over 25 additional conference and seminar talks by the PI and by L. Naples across the United States and at 1 talk in Poland. The volume of research presentations was hampered in the last two years of the award, because of the covid-19 pandemic.

The primary research was in Geometric Measure Theory, a subfield of Mathematical Analysis. Notable advances include:

  • a new parameterization technique developed by the PI, L. Naples, and V. Vellis, which led to the Holder Traveling Salesman Theorem, a new criterion for detecting when an infinite set of points lies inside of the trace of a curve of dimension greater than 1;
  • rejuvination of Martin and Mattila's theory of fractional rectifiabiilty (non-integer dimensional rectifiability) of sets and measures in work by the PI and Vellis;
  • sharp extensions by the PI and S. McCurdy of R. Schul's Analyst's Traveling Salesman Theorem in Hilbert space to arbitrary (infinite-dimensional) uniformly convex and uniformly smooth Banach spaces, including the lp spaces with p strictly between 1 and infinity;
  • solution by the PI and L. Naples of the Identification Problem for Radon Measures carried by Lipschitz graphs in arbitrary dimension and codimension, a fundamental question about the geometric structure of arbitrary finite measures, an abstract mathematical structure which encapsulates colloquial notions of length, area, and volume;
  • extension by the PI, S. Li, and S. Zimmerman of the Badger-Schul 1-rectifiablity theorem from Euclidean space to nonabelian Carnot groups, an important class of model spaces with different-than-the-usual rules of arithmetic
  • development by the PI and A. Genschaw (and correction of the original proof) of Bourgain's theorem for the dimension of harmonic measure in the setting of the heat equation, which loosely speaking says that on a domain with a very rough boundary heat applied on most of the boundary of the domain cannot effect the heat inside the domain.

This work both produced answers to old questions and opened up new directions for future explorations in geometric measure theory, harmonic analysis, metric geometry, and theory of partial differential equations.
